The descending angle also makes Oberhau effective against opponents in middle or low guards, as you can attack from above their defensive structure. Use this strike when you need to be aggressive, when you want to test your opponent's reactions, or when you need to break through passive guards. Remember Liechtenauer's principle: always strike 'with the strength of the whole body,' making the Oberhau not just an arm motion but a full-body expression of offensive intent.
records.definition: A downward strike from above (over-cut), delivered from shoulder or overhead.
records.briefDescription: A downward strike from above (over-cut), delivered from shoulder or overhead.
records.fullDescription: Execute a descending strike that travels downward from a high position toward your target. Begin with your sword raised at or above shoulder height (typically from Vom Tag or a similar high guard), then drive the blade downward with the true edge leading. The strike can be delivered vertically (straight down), or diagonally (from high on one side to low on the opposite side). Your body mechanics should generate power through full rotation and weight transfer—step forward as you cut, unwinding your body and driving your hands forward and down. Your arms extend during the strike, reaching toward your target with committed forward pressure. The Oberhau is the most natural and powerful type of strike, using gravity and body weight to amplify force. Common variations include the vertical Scheitelhau (parting strike to the crown), the diagonal Zornhau (wrath strike), and general diagonal descending cuts from right or left. Your hands should drive the cut, with the pommel and hands leading the blade's path initially, then the blade accelerating through the target. The strike typically ends in a lower position—either in a low guard or through the target.
records.briefApplication: Use Oberhau as your fundamental attacking strike throughout the German longsword tradition.

records.fullApplication:
Use Unterhau to exploit your opponent's high commitments and to attack from unexpected low angles. This strike excels at punishing opponents who overcommit to high guards or attacks, as you can rise up under their structure and strike their exposed hands, arms, or body from below. The rising path of Unterhau makes it particularly effective when rising from Alber or after your blade has been driven low—you're using the recovery motion itself as an attack.

Use this strike when your opponent has lifted high to attack or parry, creating openings below. Unterhau is also valuable in the principle of Überlaufen (overrunning), where you use a rising strike to intercept and defeat an opponent's rising attack by reaching them first with longer extension. The strike teaches important tactical lessons about using all angles of attack—don't limit yourself to descending cuts just because they're more natural.

Practice Unterhau by emphasizing leg drive and body rise: your power comes from straightening your legs and rising with your whole body, not just lifting with your arms. The strike is particularly effective when combined with footwork that closes distance while you rise, making your blade arrive with maximum extension and body weight behind it.

Use Unterhau as a counter when your opponent attacks high and you're in a low position—rise into their attack with your own rising cut, often reaching them sooner because of geometry. The strike also works well as a follow-up: strike Oberhau to bring your blade low, then immediately rise with Unterhau to the opposite side. This creates a continuous flow of cutting that's difficult to defend against. Meyer's system particularly emphasizes Unterhau in flowing sequences of cuts to all openings.

Remember that while Oberhau uses gravity as an ally, Unterhau must overcome gravity with technique and body mechanics—focus on explosive leg drive and committed forward motion.
records.definition: An upward rising strike from below toward the target.
records.briefDescription: An upward rising strike from below toward the target.
records.fullDescription: Execute an ascending strike that rises upward from a low position toward your target. Begin with your sword held low (from Alber, Pflug, or after a previous descending cut has brought your blade down), then drive the blade upward with the true edge leading. The motion reverses the path of an Oberhau—where descending cuts use gravity, rising cuts use leg drive and body unwinding to generate upward power. Step forward and rise with your body as you cut, using your legs to drive the blade upward while your arms extend and lift. The strike typically targets the opponent's hands, arms, torso, or head from below, coming up under their guard. Your hips and core should rotate to add power to the ascending motion. The Unterhau often arrives from unexpected angles since most guards and attacks emphasize high-line threats, making the rising cut a tactical surprise. The strike can be delivered vertically (rising straight up the centerline) or diagonally (rising from low on one side toward high on the opposite side). Your blade should accelerate through the target zone, and the strike typically ends in a higher position—often transitioning to Ochs or Vom Tag. Common applications include rising from Alber to intercept descending attacks, or using Unterhau after your opponent has committed high, leaving lower lines open.
records.briefApplication: Use Unterhau to exploit your opponent's high commitments and to attack from unexpected low angles.

records.fullApplication:
Use Mittelhau to attack your opponent's torso, ribs, and mid-level openings with powerful horizontal strikes that come from outside their primary defensive focus. This strike excels at exploiting openings in the middle zones that are often less protected than high or low lines. The horizontal path allows you to strike around guards rather than through them—if your opponent's blade protects the vertical centerline, you can cut horizontally around it to reach their side.

Use Mittelhau when you want to attack with body rotation power rather than gravitational force. The strike is particularly effective when your opponent is focused on defending high (against Oberhau) or preparing low attacks—the middle horizontal path surprises them. The Zwerchhau is a specialized high Mittelhau that specifically targets head and hands at shoulder-to-head height, used to dominate the high line horizontally.

Practice Mittelhau by emphasizing full body rotation: plant your feet, coil your hips, then explosively unwind through the strike. Your hands and arms extend horizontally as your body turns, creating a sweeping motion that's difficult to intercept. The strike works well in combinations: after an Oberhau brings your blade to one side low, you can immediately cut Mittelhau across to the opposite side at mid-level, then rise with Unterhau—this creates a continuous flow of strikes at different heights that overwhelms defenses.

Use Mittelhau when facing opponents in middle guards like Pflug, as you can cut horizontally to their exposed sides or arms. The horizontal nature also makes it effective for striking while moving laterally—you can sidestep and cut Mittelhau simultaneously, combining footwork with offense.

In Meyer's system, Mittelhau appears in flowing combinations where you cut to all four openings (high right, high left, low right, low left) in sequence, with Mittelhau handling the horizontal transitions. The strike teaches you to use rotational power and to attack from horizontal angles that complement the more common vertical strikes. Remember that horizontal cuts require good edge alignment and body mechanics since you don't have gravity helping—focus on keeping the blade true and your body rotation complete.
records.definition: A horizontal cut at torso height traveling across.
records.briefDescription: A horizontal cut at torso height traveling across.
records.fullDescription: Execute a horizontal strike that travels across your body at mid-level height, typically at torso, ribs, or upper leg level. The strike moves laterally from one side to the other rather than descending or ascending. Begin from a guard position on either side, then rotate your body and drive the blade horizontally across the target zone. Your arms extend as you rotate, keeping the blade path horizontal (or slightly rising/falling depending on target height). The power comes from body rotation and hip drive—imagine unwinding a spring as your torso turns. The Mittelhau can be delivered with either edge: long edge strikes typically come from your left side moving right, while short edge strikes often come from your right moving left (especially in the Zwerchhau variant). Your footwork should support the rotation: step across or pivot to add body weight to the horizontal path. The blade travels parallel to the ground through the target zone, threatening the opponent's mid-section, sides, arms, or (when aimed higher) head and neck. The Mittelhau includes both the general horizontal cuts to the body and specialized techniques like the Zwerchhau (thwart strike) which emphasizes the high horizontal line. Your hands should stay relatively level as you cut, neither rising nor falling significantly, keeping the blade on the horizontal plane.
records.briefApplication: Use Mittelhau to attack your opponent's torso, ribs, and mid-level openings with powerful horizontal strikes that come from outside their primary defensive focus.

records.fullApplication: Use the thrust (Stich) as your fastest, most direct attacking option and as the primary weapon from the binding. This technique excels at speed and precision—because the point travels in a straight line rather than an arc, it arrives faster than any cut. Use thrusts when you need to hit quickly, when you're working in the bind and need to exploit an opening, or when you want to threaten with minimal telegraphing. The thrust is central to Liechtenauer's system, particularly in the Krieg (close combat phase) where winding actions typically end in thrusts to available openings. After establishing a bind, assess pressure through fühlen, then wind your point toward openings and thrust. Use Stich from Ochs to threaten the face and upper body with high thrusts, or from Pflug to threaten the chest and torso with middle thrusts. The thrust is also the primary action in Absetzen (setting aside), where you parry by thrusting simultaneously with your defense. Practice thrusting with full body commitment: don't just extend your arms, but drive forward with your whole body, making the thrust penetrate rather than simply touch. Your point should stay on target throughout the extension—practice keeping the tip stable and online even as you move. The thrust is particularly valuable against opponents who focus on defending against cuts—they may leave their centerline open, giving you a straight path to thrust. Use Stich as a finish after your cuts have created openings: strike to draw their parry, then thrust through the opening this creates. The historical sources emphasize that 'the point threatens and finishes' while cuts prepare and create opportunities. In Meyer's system, he notes that thrusting had fallen out of favor among Germans by his time (1570) compared to earlier periods, but it remains essential in the core Liechtenauer tradition. The thrust also allows you to maintain safer distance—you can threaten and hit from maximum extension without needing to commit to the closer ranges required for effective cuts. Practice thrusting from all guards and from various binding positions until it becomes instinctive. Remember: cuts provoke reactions and create opportunities, but thrusts exploit those opportunities with speed and precision. The combination of cutting and thrusting gives you complete tactical flexibility—use each as the situation demands.
records.definition: A straight stab; one of the three wounders.
records.briefDescription: A straight stab; one of the three wounders.
records.fullDescription: Execute a linear thrust by extending your arms and driving the point directly toward your target in a straight line. The thrust is one of the 'Drei Wunder' (three wounders)—along with cuts and slices—representing the three ways to wound with the sword. Hold your sword with the point aimed at your target (typically from Ochs, Pflug, or Langort), then drive forward by straightening your arms and stepping forward with your body weight behind the thrust. Your blade should remain on the line between your hands and the target, with minimal deviation or wavering. The thrust can be directed high (to the face or throat from Ochs), middle (to the chest from Pflug or Langort), or low (to the stomach or groin from a wound position). Your body should drive behind the thrust—step forward as you extend, adding your body weight to the point's penetration. The thrust is faster than cuts because it travels the shortest distance (a straight line rather than an arc) and requires less motion. Your hands should drive forward decisively, with the point leading and your body following. The thrust can be executed from the bind (winding into a thrust), from guards (direct thrust attack), or as a follow-up to cuts. Keep your hands structured and aligned—poor structure will cause the point to wander offline. The thrust is the primary offensive action from both Ochs and Pflug, and the natural conclusion of many winding actions.
records.briefApplication: Use thrusts when you need to hit quickly, when you're working in the bind and need to exploit an opening, or when you want to threaten with minimal telegraphing.

records.fullApplication: Use slicing (Schneiden) as your primary cutting technique when you're in close range (Krieg) where full percussive cuts aren't practical but edge attacks are still possible. This technique excels at compromising your opponent's grip and structure without requiring the space or time for swinging strikes. Slices are particularly effective against hands, wrists, and forearms—targets that are often exposed during binding and close work. Use Schneiden when you're working in the bind and can reach your opponent's hands: press your edge against their wrist or forearm and slice across by pushing or pulling your blade while maintaining pressure. The slice can cause pain, disrupt their grip, compromise their structure, or in a real fight, disable their hands. Use slicing as part of your close-range tactical toolkit: establish control or contact with their blade, then slice to create an opening for your thrust or cut. The technique appears in many applications: when they lift to parry, slice across their hands (Abschneiden); when running through (Durchlaufen), use slices to control and damage; when in close binds, slice to compromise their position. Practice slicing with emphasis on edge pressure and body mechanics: the power comes from driving with your body and structure, not just sawing with your arms. Your blade should maintain contact and pressure throughout the slicing motion. Slices can be performed in any direction: forward (pushing), backward (pulling), or circularly (rotating around a pivot point). The technique is valuable because it works at ranges where cuts fail—when you're too close to swing, you can still slice. Use Schneiden against opponents who habitually lift their hands high, exposing their wrists and forearms to your slicing attacks. The historical sources describe slicing as one of the three wounders (along with cuts and thrusts), emphasizing its importance in the complete fighting system. Meyer's system includes extensive slicing techniques, particularly in close work and in the context of various grappling and wrestling applications at the sword (Ringen am Schwert). Remember that slices require different mechanics than percussive cuts: where cuts use impact and momentum, slices use sustained edge pressure with motion. Practice both pushing and pulling slices until you can execute them instinctively when opportunities appear in close range.
records.definition: A slicing attack (often to hands/arms) by pushing/pulling the edge.
records.briefDescription: A slicing attack (often to hands/arms) by pushing/pulling the edge.
records.fullDescription: Execute a slicing action by applying your blade's edge against your target and then pushing or pulling to create a drawing cut. Unlike percussive cuts (Hau) that strike with impact, slices (Schnitte) use continuous edge pressure combined with motion to cut. Place your blade's edge in contact with or very close to your target (typically your opponent's hands, wrists, forearms, or blade), then push or pull your blade across the target while maintaining edge pressure. The motion can be a push (pressing forward and across), a pull (drawing backward and across), or a rotation around a point of contact. Your body weight and structure should drive the slice—use your legs and core, not just arms. Slices are particularly effective in close range (Krieg) where full cuts don't have room to develop but edges can reach exposed limbs. The technique includes various specific applications: Abschneiden (slicing off) which slices across hands while suppressing the opponent's blade, and the Schnitte mentioned in techniques like running through (Durchlaufen) and close work. Slices can be performed with either edge and at various angles depending on your position and the target. The key is maintaining edge contact with pressure throughout the motion—the slice should feel like you're drawing the edge through the target, not just touching it. Your blade should bite into the target with the combination of edge alignment, pressure, and motion.
records.briefApplication: Use slicing (Schneiden) as your primary cutting technique when you're in close range (Krieg) where full percussive cuts aren't practical but edge attacks are still possible.

records.fullApplication: Use Versetzen as your general defensive framework, but always strive to make your displacement active and threatening rather than purely defensive. This concept excels at intercepting attacks while maintaining or creating offensive potential—the best Versetzen doesn't just block but simultaneously threatens your opponent. When you must parry, do so in a way that puts you in position to counter immediately. The four master strikes exemplify active Versetzen: each breaks a specific guard not by passively blocking but by striking in a way that simultaneously displaces and threatens. Use Zwerchhau to displace Vom Tag by cutting across high to dominate hands and head; use Krumphau to displace Ochs by crossing over to strike hands and blade; use Schielhau to displace Pflug by striking diagonally to push their point offline while your edge continues to target; use Scheitelhau to displace Alber by overrunning their rising attempt with your descending vertical cut. When performing Versetzen, maintain proper structure: use your strong part of the blade against their weak, keep your body aligned to support the displacement, and position your point to threaten as you displace. Don't think of Versetzen as a separate defensive phase—instead, see it as part of continuous action where you're constantly displacing and threatening in one motion. The concept appears throughout the system: Absetzen is a specific type of Versetzen that extends into long point while displacing; winding in the bind involves continual Versetzen as you and your opponent work to displace each other's blade while maintaining contact. Practice Versetzen by emphasizing the principle that Liechtenauer states: 'pure parrying' without simultaneous threat is dangerous and gives your opponent opportunities. Instead, displace by cutting into their attack (making your defense itself an attack), by extending with threat (Absetzen), or by positioning that naturally creates binding opportunities. Use Versetzen when you're in the Nach (defensive position) and must respond to your opponent's attack, but work to regain the Vor (initiative) through your displacement—use Indes (the instant of their action) to displace and counter simultaneously, seizing back control. Remember that the best defense in this system is often a good offense: rather than waiting to Versetzen, seize the Vor by attacking first, forcing them to displace your attacks instead. However, when you must displace, do it actively, decisively, and with simultaneous threat.
records.definition: Deflect or intercept the attack by cutting/positioning your blade.
records.briefDescription: Deflect or intercept the attack by cutting/positioning your blade.
records.fullDescription: Versetzen refers to the act of displacing, setting aside, or parrying an incoming attack by using your sword to intercept and deflect it. The term is broader than modern 'parry'—it encompasses any action that displaces the opponent's attack, including cutting into their attack (like the four Meisterhäue which 'break' the four guards), setting aside with extensions (Absetzen), or defensive positioning. Execute Versetzen by moving your blade into the path of the incoming attack with proper structure, angle, and timing to redirect it away from your body. The key principle is that in Liechtenauer's system, Versetzen should ideally be combined with offensive threat—'good' parrying creates simultaneous offense and defense (like Absetzen which parries while thrusting). The four master strikes serve as Versetzen against the four primary guards: Zwerchhau breaks Vom Tag, Krumphau breaks Ochs, Schielhau breaks Pflug, and Scheitelhau breaks Alber. Your blade should meet theirs with your strong (forte) against their weak (foible) when possible, giving you leverage advantage. Structure and positioning are critical: maintain good body alignment and blade angle so their force is redirected rather than overwhelming you. Versetzen can be performed from various guards and can transition into binding, winding, and follow-up techniques. The term appears in the Zettel as one of the Hauptstücke (chief pieces), emphasizing its fundamental importance.
records.briefApplication: Use Versetzen as your general defensive framework, but always strive to make your displacement active and threatening rather than purely defensive.

records.fullApplication: Use Nachreisen to exploit your opponent's tactical errors and transitional vulnerabilities, turning their actions against them. This technique excels at punishing poor distance judgment, telegraphed preparations, and incomplete attacks. When your opponent lifts their sword to chamber a strike, use Nachreisen to strike them during this lifting phase before they can complete their attack—your strike arrives first because you're attacking their preparation. When their attack misses because you've managed distance well (staying just outside their reach), immediately chase after with your own strike while their blade is still recovering from the miss and out of position to defend. When they pull back or change guards without proper coverage, follow after them with strikes or thrusts to capitalize on the exposed moment. The historical glosses describe Nachreisen as attacking when the opponent 'goes up' (lifts to strike), when they 'miss' or 'strike past,' and when they 'pull back' or 'spring away.' This is a Nach (defensive/responsive) technique that allows you to regain the Vor (initiative) by exploiting their mistakes. Practice Nachreisen by developing good distance judgment: position yourself just outside your opponent's effective range, making them commit fully to reach you, then as their attack misses or they prepare, travel after with your own attack. The technique teaches important tactical lessons about timing (tempo) and distance. Use Nachreisen when facing aggressive opponents who telegraph their attacks or attack from too far—let them commit, then chase after them. The technique also works against defensive opponents who habitually pull back after each exchange—follow their withdrawal with pursuing strikes. Nachreisen requires patience and discipline: don't attack prematurely, but wait for the right moment when they're truly exposed. The technique connects to the broader concept of 'True Times' in the Liechtenauer tradition: there are specific moments when attacks will succeed, and Nachreisen exploits the True Time of your opponent's vulnerability. Meyer's system also emphasizes Nachreisen as a way to crowd into openings created by the opponent's actions. Practice this technique with a partner: have them make deliberate preparations, misses, or guard changes, and work on timing your Nachreisen to hit them in these exposed moments. As you improve, the deliberate practice becomes instinctive recognition of opportunities in free fencing. Remember that Nachreisen isn't just about speed but about timing—striking at the right moment when they're vulnerable, not just striking fast. The technique embodies the principle that you should exploit every opportunity your opponent creates through their own actions.
records.definition: Exploit their miss/recovery by striking in the Nach.
records.briefDescription: Exploit their miss/recovery by striking in the Nach.
records.fullDescription: Nachreisen (traveling after, chasing, following after) is the technique of attacking your opponent during their preparation, miss, or recovery—essentially, pursuing them with your attack as they expose themselves through their own actions. The concept has several applications: (1) Attacking into their preparation when they lift their sword or chamber an attack, hitting them before they can complete their action; (2) Attacking after they miss, striking them while their blade has passed by and they're momentarily unable to defend; (3) Attacking when they withdraw or change guards without proper coverage, catching them in the transition. Execute Nachreisen by maintaining awareness of your opponent's actions and immediately exploiting any moment where they create openings. When you see them begin to lift for a strike, strike into that lifting motion before they can complete their attack—your attack arrives first because you're already in motion while they're still preparing. When their attack misses (because you've voided or they've misjudged distance), immediately strike to their now-open line while their sword is out of position. When they pull back or change guards, follow after with strikes or thrusts to the openings this creates. Your timing must be precise: Nachreisen works in the moment (Indes) between their commitment and their recovery. Step forward as you strike, closing distance to ensure your attack reaches them. The technique requires good distance judgment and the patience to wait for—or create—these moments rather than attacking prematurely.
records.briefApplication: Use Nachreisen to exploit your opponent's tactical errors and transitional vulnerabilities, turning their actions against them.

records.fullApplication: Use Überlaufen to decisively defeat opponents who favor low guards or who attempt to rise from below with attacks. This technique excels at exploiting the geometric disadvantage of low positions—when they must rise a long distance to attack or defend, you can descend from above over a shorter path and reach them first. The Scheitelhau (scalp strike) is the primary Überlaufen technique against Alber: when your opponent is in the Fool guard, attack with a vertical descending cut directly to their crown; if they attempt to rise to parry or attack, your descending strike overruns theirs because you're already in motion from above while they must rise from below. Use Überlaufen when you see opponents preparing to rise from low positions—don't wait for them to complete their preparation, but attack immediately from above, reaching them first. The technique requires commitment: you must extend fully and strike decisively, not tentatively. If you hesitate or strike short, their rising attack may reach you first, defeating the purpose of overrunning. Practice Überlaufen by emphasizing speed, extension, and commitment when striking from above. Your body should drive forward as you descend, making your attack reach maximum extension. The technique teaches the tactical principle that position matters: high positions have advantages over low positions in terms of reach and timing. Use Überlaufen against Alber specifically, but also against any situation where your opponent is low and must rise to engage you. The technique also applies when your opponent attempts rising attacks (Unterhau) from low positions—you can overrun their rising attack by descending from above with better timing and extension. Historical sources emphasize that Überlaufen is about reaching them first through superior position and commitment, not about blocking their attack. You're winning the race to the target by having a shorter, more advantageous path. Practice timing: recognize when they begin to rise or prepare from low, and immediately launch your descending attack, overrunning their attempt. The technique connects to the broader principle of seizing the Vor (initiative) through superior positioning and timing. Use Überlaufen when you have the high ground (literally) and they're positioned low—exploit this advantage by attacking from above with full commitment. Remember that the key is extending fully and striking decisively—tentative or short overrunning attempts will fail. Commit fully to reaching them first from your superior high position, and the geometric advantage will make your attack arrive before theirs.
records.definition: Beat low attacks with higher, longer over-cuts.
records.briefDescription: Beat low attacks with higher, longer over-cuts.
records.fullDescription: Überlaufen (overrunning, overreaching) is the technique of defeating your opponent's low or rising attacks by attacking from above with longer extension and better timing, essentially 'overrunning' their attack by reaching them first from a superior position. The principle is that attacks from above with proper extension will reach your opponent before their lower or rising attacks can reach you, particularly when they're coming from low guards like Alber. Execute Überlaufen by recognizing when your opponent is preparing to rise from below or attack from a low position, then attack from above with full extension and commitment, reaching them before their attack can complete. Your descending strike (typically Scheitelhau or Oberhau) should extend fully, driving your point or edge toward their head or upper body while their blade is still rising from below. The technique works because of geometric advantage: the descending path from above is shorter and more direct than the rising path from below, and gravity assists your descending strike while opposing their rising one. Your body should commit forward fully, adding reach and power to your descending attack. The technique specifically applies against Alber and other low guards where the opponent must rise significantly to defend or attack—your overhead strike reaches them before they can get their point up. Maintain strong structure and extend fully—half-committed Überlaufen fails because your opponent's rising attack may reach you first if you don't fully commit to overrunning them.
records.briefApplication: Use Überlaufen to decisively defeat opponents who favor low guards or who attempt to rise from below with attacks.

records.fullApplication: Use Fühlen as your primary sensory tool for decision-making in the bind (Krieg phase). This skill excels at transforming blade contact from a simple physical interaction into an information-gathering opportunity that dictates your tactical choices. When your blade contacts your opponent's, immediately feel whether they're hard or soft, then respond appropriately. If you feel hard (strong) pressure—they're pushing firmly against your blade—use techniques that work with or around their strength rather than against it: Zucken (pull away suddenly, letting their pressure push into empty space), Durchwechseln (change through under their blade while they're committed to controlling your current line), or certain applications of winding that use their pressure to create openings. If you feel soft (weak) pressure—they're not pushing, or they're yielding—use techniques that exploit this weakness: press through with winding thrusts, execute Mutieren (winding over their blade to thrust low while trapping it), or simply cut or thrust directly through their weak defense. The historical sources emphasize that Fühlen is critical: 'Learn how to feel, Indes is a sharp word.' This means you must feel the pressure state, then act in the instant (Indes) based on what you feel. Fühlen is not mystical or about meditation—it's practical tactile sensing. Your hands, arms, and blade act as an extension of your awareness, gathering physical information through contact. Practice Fühlen by drilling with a partner: establish blade contact, have them vary their pressure (hard, soft, neutral), and practice recognizing these states and responding appropriately. Over time, this becomes automatic—you feel pressure and your body responds with the correct technique without conscious thought. Fühlen is what separates advanced fencers from beginners: beginners just strike, while advanced fencers use blade contact to gather information and make intelligent tactical choices. Use Fühlen constantly when in the bind—never waste blade contact by failing to sense and respond to pressure. The skill also teaches broader tactical awareness: if you're consistently feeling hard pressure, perhaps your opponent is over-committed and you should exploit this; if you're consistently feeling soft pressure, perhaps they're passive and you should press your attacks more aggressively. Fühlen connects to the principle of 'hard against soft, soft against hard'—you should respond to their pressure state with the complementary action, never meeting their strength with your strength (which becomes a contest of force) but instead exploiting their state with appropriate technique. Remember that Fühlen is not about absolute force measurement but about tactical states: recognizing whether they're controlling, yielding, or neutral, and responding appropriately. Develop this skill through extensive binding practice until it becomes your automatic response to blade contact.
records.definition: Read pressure in contact to choose the correct follow-up.
records.briefDescription: Read pressure in contact to choose the correct follow-up.
records.fullDescription: Fühlen (feeling, sensing) is the skill of perceiving your opponent's pressure, intention, and commitment through blade contact in the bind, allowing you to choose the appropriate response. This is a tactile sense, not a mystical concept—when your blades are in contact, you can physically feel whether your opponent is hard (strong, pushing) or soft (weak, yielding) in the bind. Develop Fühlen by maintaining alert awareness when your blades touch: notice the pressure they exert, whether they're pressing forward, yielding backward, or maintaining neutral pressure. Your hands and arms should act as sensors, gathering information through the blade contact. The feeling should be instantaneous—as soon as you establish contact, you should register their pressure state. Based on what you feel, choose your response: if hard (strong pressure), use techniques that yield and work around their strength (Zucken, Durchwechseln, Mutieren in some contexts); if soft (weak pressure), use techniques that press through their weakness (winding to thrust, Duplieren in some contexts, direct cuts or thrusts through the bind). Fühlen is not about measuring exact force but about recognizing tactical states: are they committed and pressing (hard), or passive and not controlling (soft)? This information tells you which techniques will work. The skill develops through practice—initially, you must consciously think about what you feel, but with experience, Fühlen becomes automatic and you respond instinctively to pressure states. Fühlen works in conjunction with Indes (acting in the instant)—you feel the pressure and immediately respond based on that information.
records.briefApplication: Use Fühlen as your primary sensory tool for decision-making in the bind (Krieg phase).

records.fullApplication:
Use Durchlaufen when your opponent extends their arms forward and creates the opportunity for you to rush inside their reach before they can withdraw. This technique excels at transforming sword fencing into wrestling, taking the fight to a range where your grappling skills decide the outcome rather than swordplay. When you see your opponent thrust, hold a forward guard like Langort, or otherwise extend their arms forward, immediately rush forward inside their arms before they can withdraw their point to threaten you.

The technique requires explosive commitment: don't hesitate or run through tentatively, but drive forward decisively past their point. As you run through, protect yourself: duck slightly or angle your head away from their crossguard to avoid head injury, and use your sword to control or block theirs as you close. Grip your sword at both the hilt and the blade to give you more control and leverage options in close range.

Once you've successfully run through and closed inside their arms, immediately transition to wrestling techniques: execute throws using your sword as a lever against their neck or arms, attempt takedowns by disrupting their base, apply arm locks or joint manipulations, strike with your pommel to vulnerable targets, or attempt to disarm them (Schwertnehmen) by controlling their sword and stripping it away.

The sources describe Durchlaufen as particularly effective against opponents who rely on extended guards and long-range tactics—you're taking away their range advantage by closing inside it. Practice Durchlaufen by developing the ability to recognize when arms are extended, explosive forward movement, and smooth transitions to wrestling techniques. Work with protective gear since this technique naturally leads to close physical contact and grappling.

The technique teaches important lessons about range: there are multiple fighting distances (long range for cuts, middle range for binding, close range for wrestling), and you can deliberately change the range to your advantage. Use Durchlaufen when you're confident in your wrestling skills and want to negate your opponent's sword advantage, or when you've created a moment where their arms are extended and you can exploit this.

The historical sources emphasize that Durchlaufen is for countering opponents who 'like to run in'—meaning it works both as a technique you initiate and as a counter when they attempt it. Be prepared to defend against Durchlaufen by not overextending your arms, maintaining mobility, and being ready to withdraw your point or strike them as they attempt to close.

Remember that running through is a commitment: once you initiate, you must follow through completely. Don't use Durchlaufen carelessly, but when the moment is right and their arms are extended, commit fully to rushing inside and transitioning to wrestling. This technique embodies the principle that the longsword system includes all ranges of combat, from long cuts through binding work to close grappling—a complete martial system.
records.definition: Crash inside range to initiate ringen am schwert.
records.briefDescription: Crash inside range to initiate ringen am schwert.
records.fullDescription:
Durchlaufen (running through) is the technique of rushing inside your opponent's extended sword arms to initiate close-range grappling and wrestling at the sword (Ringen am Schwert). Execute this technique when your opponent's arms are extended forward (such as after a thrust or when they're holding a forward guard), creating a moment where you can run past their sword point by getting inside their arms. Rush forward decisively, dropping your hips slightly and driving forward under their extended arms.

As you run through, maintain control of your sword—either by gripping it at blade and hilt to use it as a lever, or by positioning it to block or control their sword as you close. Your goal is to close distance so rapidly that you pass their point before they can withdraw it to stab you.

Once inside their arms, you transition immediately to wrestling techniques: throws, takedowns, arm locks, blade disarms (Schwertnehmen), pommel strikes, or other close-combat techniques. Protect yourself as you run through: keep your head away from their crossguard, control their arms or blade as you close, and maintain your base and structure.

The technique requires commitment and timing: you must see the moment when their arms are extended and commit fully to rushing inside before they can recover. Half-committed running through leaves you vulnerable. Durchlaufen appears in the sources as a response to specific situations and as a counter to opponents who like to use long-range tactics or who extend their arms forward frequently.
records.briefApplication: Use Durchlaufen when your opponent extends their arms forward and creates the opportunity for you to rush inside their reach before they can withdraw.

records.fullApplication: Use Ansetzen to capitalize instantly on any opening your opponent creates, emphasizing immediate offensive exploitation rather than waiting or preparing. This technique excels at teaching the tactical principle of immediate action: when you see an opening, take it now, not after consideration or preparation. The moment your opponent's sword moves offline, their body becomes exposed, or their guard opens—immediately set your point onto their face, throat, or chest with a direct thrust. The technique works at all phases of fencing: in Zufechten (approach) if they present an opening, immediately thrust to it rather than continuing to approach; in the bind (Krieg) if winding or other actions create an opening, immediately set your point onto it; after displacing their attack, immediately set your point to the newly opened line. Practice Ansetzen by developing constant point awareness: your point should always be threatening and ready to extend instantly to openings. Don't think of thrusting as a separate action that requires preparation—instead, think of your point as constantly seeking targets, and Ansetzen as simply allowing it to reach the target the instant it becomes available. The technique emphasizes speed and decisiveness: slow or hesitant Ansetzen allows your opponent to close the opening or defend, while immediate Ansetzen catches them before they can react. Use Ansetzen particularly when your opponent raises their hands or sword for attacks, creating openings below; when they withdraw, creating momentary gaps; or when they change guards without proper coverage. The technique connects to the principle of seizing the Vor (initiative): by immediately setting your point onto openings, you force them into the Nach (defensive position) where they must react to your threat. Historical sources emphasize that you should thrust to openings 'without danger'—meaning you should position and time your Ansetzen so you're threatening them without exposing yourself unduly. Practice by drilling: have a partner open various lines momentarily, and work on thrusting immediately to those openings as they appear. Develop the instinct that opening = thrust, with no delay. The technique teaches tactical awareness and decisiveness: you must see openings immediately and act on them instantly. Ansetzen is not about powerful thrusts but about quick, direct thrusts that arrive while the opening exists. Use this technique constantly in all phases of fencing—let your point always be seeking targets and immediately extend when targets become available. Remember that the best defense creates offense: after you've displaced their attack (Versetzen), immediately Ansetzen to their newly opened line, combining defense and offense in one flowing action. The technique embodies the principle that 'the point threatens and finishes'—use Ansetzen to make good on that threat by actually reaching their body immediately when opportunities arise.
records.definition: Immediate face/chest thrust at the first opening.
records.briefDescription: Immediate face/chest thrust at the first opening.
records.fullDescription: Ansetzen (setting on, placing on) is the technique of immediately setting your point onto your opponent's face, throat, or chest at the first available opportunity, creating an immediate threat that they must address. The technique emphasizes speed and directness: as soon as an opening appears, thrust your point directly to that target without hesitation or preparation. Execute Ansetzen by maintaining your point forward and ready (typically from Langort, Ochs, or Pflug), then as soon as you see an opening—whether in the approach (Zufechten) or in the fight (Krieg)—immediately extend to thrust to that opening. Your arms should extend decisively, driving the point forward with your body weight behind it. The thrust should arrive quickly and directly, giving your opponent no time to react before they must defend. Ansetzen can be used from various situations: when your opponent raises their sword for an attack (leaving their lower body open), when they withdraw or change guards (creating momentary openings), after you've displaced their attack (opening lines), or whenever their sword is offline and you can reach them. The technique emphasizes the principle of taking the opening immediately when it appears, not waiting or preparing. Your point should be constantly threatening, and the moment an opening materializes, your point should already be driving toward it. Ansetzen is often combined with or executed during other techniques: you might Absetzen (set aside their attack) and then Ansetzen (set your point onto their opening) in a continuous motion.
records.briefApplication: Use Ansetzen to capitalize instantly on any opening your opponent creates, emphasizing immediate offensive exploitation rather than waiting or preparing.

records.fullApplication: Use the principle of Vor as your primary tactical goal in all fencing: strive to be the one acting first and force your opponent into defensive reactions. This concept excels at framing your tactical mindset: rather than waiting to see what your opponent does, make them react to what you do. Achieve the Vor by winning the Vorschlag (first strike)—strike first with a committed, threatening attack to their openings before they can strike you. Your attack must be genuine threat: strike to actual openings with committed force and proper distance, not tentative probes they can easily ignore. Once you've achieved Vor through successful first attack, maintain it by continuing to press: if they parry, immediately work to their next opening using winding, cutting from one opening to another, or thrusting as appropriate; don't pause or give them time to establish their own attacks. The sources describe the Vor as 'coming before with a strike or thrust to his opening, sooner than he comes to you, so he must parry you. Then work nimbly (Indes) in the parry, from one opening to the other, so he may not come to any technique before your work.' This describes both achieving and maintaining the Vor: strike first (achieving), then continue working before they can establish their techniques (maintaining). Practice achieving Vor by developing aggressive, committed attacking from the approach (Zufechten): don't hesitate or wait to see what they do, but strike decisively to their openings as you enter measure. Practice maintaining Vor by drilling continuous work: strike, and when they parry, immediately strike/thrust to the next opening, and continue this flowing aggression that never lets them establish their own actions. The Vor gives you control of the fight's tempo and forces your opponent into defensive mode, but you must maintain it actively—if you pause or attack tentatively, they can seize the Vor from you. The concept connects deeply to the mindset of proactive rather than reactive fighting: rather than thinking 'what will they do and how will I respond,' think 'what am I going to do to make them respond.' Use Vor as your default tactical stance: enter fights seeking to win the first strike and force them into Nach. However, recognize that the Vor can shift: if they successfully defend and establish their own attack, they now have the Vor and you're in Nach. When this happens, use defensive techniques to regain the Vor: parry with simultaneous threat (Absetzen), counter-attack in the instant of their action (Indes), or use other techniques to seize back control. The sources say 'strive for the Vor' and 'if you cannot come to the Vor, wait upon the Nach'—meaning Vor is superior, but if you must fight from Nach, do it skillfully to regain Vor. Practice tactical awareness: recognize when you have Vor (you're attacking, they're defending) and when you're in Nach (they're attacking, you're defending), and work always to achieve or maintain Vor. The concept fundamentally shapes how you approach fighting: be aggressive, attack first with commitment, and maintain offensive pressure to keep your opponent perpetually defending.
records.definition: Seize control by acting so they must respond.
records.briefDescription: Seize control by acting so they must respond.
records.fullDescription: Vor (before, initiative) is the state of acting first and maintaining offensive pressure, forcing your opponent into defensive reactions. When you have the Vor, you are attacking—striking, thrusting, or pressing forward with actions that demand responses from your opponent. The concept is fundamentally about who is acting and who is reacting: the person in the Vor is acting (making attacks that threaten), while the person in the Nach is reacting (defending against those attacks). Achieve the Vor by striking first with a real threat—not just any action, but an action that actually threatens your opponent and forces them to defend. Your attack must demand an answer: if you strike to their opening, they must parry; if you thrust to their face, they must defend; if you press forward aggressively, they must respond. Maintain the Vor by continuing to work aggressively even after your initial attack: if they parry your strike, immediately work to the next opening in the bind (winding, thrusting, striking from one opening to another); if they defend, immediately press with follow-up attacks; don't give them time to establish their own attacks. The Vor is not just physical position but tactical state: you control the tempo, dictate the actions, and force them to respond to you rather than implementing their own plans. The sources emphasize that being in the Vor is superior because your opponent is busy defending rather than attacking, but you must maintain real threat—wild, easily avoided attacks don't give you true Vor even though you're technically acting first.

records.fullApplication: Use the concept of Nach to frame your defensive mindset: when your opponent has achieved the Vor and you must defend, do so intelligently and aggressively to regain the initiative. Fighting in the Nach excels when you can transform defensive situations into counter-offensive opportunities through smart technique choice. When you find yourself in Nach (they attacked first and you must respond), don't simply parry passively—instead, defend in ways that simultaneously create threat: use Absetzen to parry while thrusting, strike into their attack with the Meisterhäue that break guards, or use other active defenses that make them defend even as you're responding to their attack. Your priority in Nach is to regain the Vor: immediately after defending their attack, work Indes (in the instant) to attack their openings before they can continue their offensive pressure. If they strike and you parry, immediately work to strike/thrust to their newly opened lines in the bind; if they thrust and you displace, immediately set your point onto their openings. The sources emphasize: 'Those are the counters against all techniques which he performs upon you. When he comes before so that you must parry him, work Indes with the parry nimbly to the nearest opening so you land a hit on him sooner than he brings his technique. In this way you win back the Vor.' This describes the Nach strategy completely: defend (must parry), then immediately counter (work Indes to opening), thereby regaining the Vor. Practice Nach by drilling defensive responses that flow immediately into offense: parry-thrust, displace-cut, intercept-wind combinations that don't pause between defense and counter. The Nach teaches important tactical lessons: (1) sometimes you will be defending—accept this and defend well; (2) defense should create offense—don't just block; (3) work immediately to regain initiative—don't stay in Nach longer than necessary. The sources say 'if you may not come to the Vor, wait upon the Nach'—meaning if you can't win the first strike, let them attack and respond skillfully to regain control. Use Nach intentionally in some situations: you can deliberately invite attacks to draw your opponent into committing, then counter their commitment. This is tactical Nach—using defensive positioning to create opportunities. However, avoid being forced into Nach by hesitation or poor tactics—strive for Vor, accept Nach when necessary, but work immediately to regain Vor. Practice recognizing when you're in Nach: if you're reacting to their actions, you're in Nach; if they're attacking and you're defending, you're in Nach. Once you recognize this state, immediately work to change it through decisive counters that force them into defense. The concept of Nach pairs with Vor as complementary states: one person has Vor while the other has Nach, and the fight involves each trying to maintain or seize the Vor. Good fencing involves both achieving Vor when possible and fighting skillfully in Nach when necessary. Remember that Nach is not about submission or pure defense—it's about smart, active responses that create opportunities to seize back control. Even when defending, maintain the mindset of seeking openings and opportunities to counter-attack effectively.
records.definition: Defend/counter as they act; reclaim the Vor.
records.briefDescription: Defend/counter as they act; reclaim the Vor.
records.fullDescription: Nach (after, defensive position) is the state of responding to your opponent's attacks rather than initiating your own—you are defending against their offensive actions. When you are in the Nach, your opponent has the Vor (initiative) and you must address their attacks before you can establish your own offense. The Nach is not inherently bad, but it's inferior to having the Vor because you're reacting to their actions rather than controlling the fight. Execute fighting in the Nach by defending intelligently rather than purely passively: use techniques like Absetzen (parrying with simultaneous thrust), striking into their attacks (the Meisterhäue which break guards), or other responses that simultaneously defend and threaten. Your goal when in the Nach is to regain the Vor (initiative) as quickly as possible. Do this by responding to their attack with a counter that forces them into defense: if they strike and you parry, immediately work Indes (in the instant) to strike/thrust to their openings, turning the tables so they must now defend your attack; if they bind with you, feel (fühlen) their pressure and exploit it immediately with winding or other techniques. The sources describe Nach as 'those are the counters against all techniques which he performs upon you'—meaning Nach is about countering their actions while working to regain control. The key principle is that being in Nach doesn't mean being passive: even when responding to their attacks, you should do so in ways that create offensive threat and opportunity to seize back the Vor.
records.briefApplication: Use the concept of Nach to frame your defensive mindset: when your opponent has achieved the Vor and you must defend, do so intelligently and aggressively to regain the initiative.

records.fullApplication: Use the principle of Indes as your timing framework for acting in the immediate moment of opportunity, particularly for interrupting your opponent's actions before they complete or exploiting transitional vulnerabilities. This concept excels at teaching instant response: rather than waiting for your opponent to complete their action and then responding (which is slower and reactive), you act during their action, in the instant when they're committed but not yet complete. Practice Indes in multiple contexts: (1) In the approach (Zufechten), when they begin to lift or prepare an attack, strike Indes during their preparation, hitting them before they can complete their attack. This is a form of Nachreisen, but emphasizing the instantaneous timing of acting during their preparation. (2) In the bind (Krieg), when you feel their pressure (Fühlen), immediately work Indes based on what you feel: if hard, immediately Zucken or wind around; if soft, immediately thrust or press through. Don't think or pause—feel and act Indes, simultaneously. The sources emphasize: 'Indes, that sharp word, is the key that unlocks the art'—meaning instant action in the moment is what makes the system work. (3) After parrying, work Indes to the next opening: they attack, you parry, and Indes (in that same instant, without pause) you strike/thrust to their opening. The parry and counter flow together as one continuous action. (4) When they change guards or withdraw, act Indes during their transition before they complete it, exploiting the moment when they're in motion and vulnerable. Practice Indes by developing instant perception-action loops: see opportunity → act immediately, with no conscious thought or delay between. This requires extensive training until responses become automatic. Drill with partners: they begin various actions, you work Indes to interrupt or exploit those actions. Focus on acting during their motion, not after. The concept teaches that there are windows of opportunity during your opponent's actions—moments when they're committed, in motion, or transitioning—and acting Indes means exploiting these windows instantly. The timing is simultaneous or overlapping: both of you are in motion, but your action interrupts or exploits theirs because you're acting in the moment of their vulnerability. Indes connects deeply to both Vor and Nach: if you're in Vor, work Indes to maintain offensive pressure (they parry, you immediately strike next opening); if you're in Nach, work Indes to regain Vor (they attack, you parry and immediately counter Indes). The concept also pairs with Fühlen: feel their pressure, act Indes based on that feeling—the two concepts work together as perception (Fühlen) and instant action (Indes). Practice Indes until it becomes your automatic response mode: opportunities appear, you act immediately, without thought or delay. This is the 'sharpness' of Indes—the instantaneous, decisive action that exploits moments before they pass. Remember that Indes is not about speed alone but about timing: acting in the right instant, during the window of opportunity, whether that instant is fast or slow. The key is acting during their action or transition, exploiting the moment, not waiting for it to complete. Master Indes and you can interrupt your opponent's techniques before they complete, exploit every transitional vulnerability, and maintain offensive pressure that never gives them time to establish their own actions. This is the highest level of tactical timing in the system.
records.definition: Exploit the transitional moment to hit while they move.
records.briefDescription: Exploit the transitional moment to hit while they move.
records.fullDescription: Indes (in the instant, meanwhile, during) is the concept of acting in the immediate moment of opportunity—specifically, acting during your opponent's action before they complete it. The term describes simultaneous or overlapping timing: you act while they're still acting, intercepting their technique before it completes or exploiting the transitional moment during their action. Indes is not about acting after their action finishes (that would be Nach), but rather acting in the midst of their action, during the window of opportunity their motion creates. Execute Indes by maintaining alert awareness and instant readiness: when you see them begin an action (lifting to strike, withdrawing, changing guards, committing to an attack), immediately act during that motion before they complete it. Your action interrupts or exploits their action: if they lift to strike, you strike Indes during their lifting motion, hitting them before their strike completes; if they bind and push hard, you act Indes to exploit their committed pressure with Zucken or winding; if they parry your attack, you work Indes in the parry to hit the next opening before they can establish their counter. The concept emphasizes instantaneous response: there's no thinking or delay, just immediate action based on what you perceive. Indes is closely linked with Fühlen (feeling)—you feel their pressure or action, then act Indes based on that information. The sources describe Indes as a 'sharp word,' emphasizing its critical importance. Mastery of Indes means you can respond instantly to opportunities, acting in the window between their commitment and completion, or between their actions.
